questions.question: Which ancient culture started kissing?
questions.funFact: This practice spread along ancient trade routes!
questions.story: The earliest written mentions of kissing come from Sanskrit texts from India, dating back to 1500 BCE. The practice spread to the Mediterranean through Alexander the Great's army after they observed it in India, eventually becoming a worldwide custom.

questions.question: Which Valentine symbol was originally a medicine?
questions.funFact: Ancient civilizations used this as currency!
questions.story: The Aztecs believed chocolate was a gift from the gods and used it as medicine. Spanish explorers brought it to Europe, where it was initially sold in pharmacies as a cure for various ailments before becoming a popular confection.

questions.question: Which country celebrates Valentine's in June?
questions.funFact: This celebration coincides with harvest festivals!
questions.story: Brazilians celebrate Dia dos Namorados (Lovers' Day) on June 12, the day before St. Anthony's Day. St. Anthony is known as the marriage saint, and the celebration includes traditional matchmaking customs and gift exchanges.

questions.question: Which flower means secret love?
questions.funFact: These blooms were once worth their weight in gold!
questions.story: In the Victorian era's language of flowers, gardenias represented secret love and sweet dreams. These fragrant flowers were so valuable that they were often transported in special cases and given as precious gifts among the aristocracy.

questions.question: Which bird mates for life?
questions.funFact: These birds can live for over 50 years!
questions.story: Albatrosses perform elaborate courtship dances that they remember throughout their lives. Once paired, they return to the same nesting site year after year, performing the same dance with their partner, even after years of separation at sea.

questions.question: Which Valentine candy was originally medicine?
questions.funFact: The original versions were much larger than today's candies!
questions.story: Conversation hearts began as medicinal lozenges in the 1840s. Pharmacist Oliver Chase invented a machine to make them more efficiently. His brother later added the idea of printing messages on the candies, starting a Valentine's Day tradition.

questions.question: Which country has love spoons?
questions.funFact: Each carving pattern has a special meaning!
questions.story: Welsh love spoons are hand-carved wooden spoons given as romantic gifts. The tradition dates back to the 17th century when sailors would carve them during long voyages. Different symbols carved into the spoons represent different wishes for the relationship.

questions.question: Which Valentine color meant friendship?
questions.funFact: This color was once considered sacred in ancient cultures!
questions.story: In Victorian times, different rose colors conveyed different messages in the language of flowers. While red roses symbolized passionate love, yellow roses represented friendship and caring. This color coding system was used to send secret messages.

questions.question: Which animal represents fidelity?
questions.funFact: These birds perform unique courtship dances!
questions.story: Turtle doves have been symbols of devoted love since ancient times. They appear in Shakespeare's works and in the famous '12 Days of Christmas' song. The birds form strong pair bonds and often return to the same nesting sites year after year.

questions.question: Which Valentine gift was once banned?
questions.funFact: People used to send them anonymously at midnight!
questions.story: In the 1600s, Valentine's cards were banned in several European countries because they were considered a form of gambling. People would put cards into a pile, and each person would draw one to find their Valentine, leading to concerns about improper matches.

questions.question: Which city receives most valentines?
questions.story: Loveland, Colorado processes over 100,000 valentines annually through its special Valentine Re-mailing Program, adding a special postmark and verse before forwarding them worldwide.

questions.question: Which Valentine's stamp glows?
questions.funFact: The design took months to perfect!
questions.story: Australia's 2015 Love Hearts stamp featured thermochromic ink that revealed a hidden message when warmed by touch, making it the world's first heat-sensitive postage stamp.

questions.question: Which Valentine's cake flies?
questions.story: Japan's Floating Heart cake uses a special meringue technique developed in the 1800s that makes the heart-shaped cake appear to float above the plate when served.

questions.question: Which Valentine tree blooms pink?
questions.story: Taiwan Cherry trees bloom precisely during Valentine's season, with their five-petaled flowers naturally forming heart shapes, making them a popular spot for Valentine's Day celebrations.

questions.question: Which Valentine bridge glows red?
questions.story: Edmonton's High Level Bridge is illuminated with 60,000 LED lights every Valentine's Day, creating a spectacular light show that attracts thousands of visitors.

questions.question: Which Valentine's museum is oldest?
questions.story: Cologne's Chocolate Museum, founded in 1993, houses the world's largest collection of Valentine's Day chocolate boxes and molds, with some pieces dating back to the 18th century.

questions.question: Which Valentine's letter is longest?
questions.story: Elizabeth Barrett Browning's love letter to Robert Browning, written in 1845, is 20 pages long and is considered the longest preserved Valentine's Day letter in history.

questions.question: Which Valentine's perfume is rarest?
questions.story: Clive Christian's 'Imperial Majesty' perfume, released for Valentine's Day 2006, was limited to 10 bottles, each featuring a 5-carat white diamond on the neck.

questions.question: Which Valentine's ring is biggest?
questions.story: The Taylor-Burton Diamond, given as a Valentine's gift in 1969, weighs 69.42 carats and was so valuable it required its own security team when worn in public.

questions.question: Which Valentine's garden is largest?
questions.story: Dubai Miracle Garden creates the world's largest Valentine's Day display each year, using over 50 million flowers to form massive heart-shaped structures and romantic scenes.

questions.question: Which Valentine's card is oldest?
questions.story: The oldest known Valentine's card was written in 1477 by Margery Brews to her fiancé John Paston in Norfolk, England. The letter, now in the British Library, expresses her love and calls John her 'right well-beloved Valentine'.

questions.question: Which Valentine's cave glows?
questions.story: New Zealand's Waitomo Caves host special Valentine's Day boat rides where couples float under thousands of bioluminescent glowworms, creating a natural starry ceiling effect.

questions.question: Which Valentine's chocolate is priciest?
questions.story: Le Grand Louis XVI by Debauve & Gallais is the world's most expensive Valentine's chocolate, priced at over $900 per pound. Each piece is made with rare cocoa and edible 24-karat gold leaf.

questions.question: Which Valentine's rose lasts longest?
questions.story: The Forever Rose, developed in Ecuador, can last up to three years without water through a special preservation process. Each rose is treated with a patented solution that maintains its fresh appearance.

questions.question: Which Valentine's festival is coldest?
questions.story: China's Harbin Ice Festival features a special Valentine's Day celebration where couples can exchange vows in a palace made entirely of ice, illuminated by colorful LED lights in -20°C temperatures.
